reinferces the
control of the d4 square and allows the "spanish" Bishop to avoid the exchange
in case it is attacked by the Knights.  9...

21...

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. c3 Be7 10. Re1 O-O 11. Nd4 Nxd4 12. cxd4 c6 13. f3 Ng5 14. Nc3 Bf5 15. g4 Bc8 16. f4 b4 17. Na4 Ne4 18. f5 Bg5 19. Qf3 Bxc1 20. Raxc1 Qh4 21. Re2 Ng5 22. Qg3 Qxg3+ 23. hxg3 Nf3+ 24. Kf2 Nxd4
comment:
In this way Pollock wins a wonderful pawn. It looks,
however, that Pillsbury, already since his 21st move (21.Re2) has already
calculated everything until here and beyond. Let's see what plan he has
thought to have some compensation for the sacrificed material.

comment:
To free the Knight it is necessary to go down and protect the pawn e5. Notice
that 4 white pawns out of 5 are on dark squares. The Black lightsquared Bishop,
if it is not already, it going to become a "bad" Bishop.  38...

comment:
Once again
Black is a pawn up. Not only, he has the "h" pawn free to rush towards his
promoting square, which is quite controlled by the Bishop? Why is Pollock not
smiling? Omens?

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Nxe4 6. d4 b5 7. Bb3 d5 8. dxe5 Be6 9. c3 Be7 10. Re1 O-O 11. Nd4 Nxd4 12. cxd4 c6 13. f3 Ng5 14. Nc3 Bf5 15. g4 Bc8 16. f4 b4 17. Rxc6 Rfe8 34. Rc7 Kg8 35. Kh6 Bf3 36. Re7 Kf8 37. Rxe8+ Rxe8 38. Kg5 Be4 39. Kf4 Rc8 40. Nxb4 Rc5 41. Nxa6 Rb5 42. Ke3 Rxb3+ 43. Kd4 Rxg3 44. Nc5 h4 45. b4 h3 46. Ra2
comment:
! - Threatens mate. But the
exclamation mark is not for the threat. The move deserves the exclamation mark
because forces the opponent's King to go away by one tempo. "Why one tempo? -
asks my granddaughter, who is sitting with me and is watching the game - You
mean one square." "Uhmm. You see... on the chessboard often they are the same
thing".  46...
